There‚Äôs more. If Roubini wants to tackle problems, rather than finding fault, more power to him.  Careful observers might note that the ‚ÄúUnited Sovereign Governance Gold Optimized Dollar‚Äù resembles another project that had ambitions of Global Reserve Status and to help underserved communities: Libra! Facebook‚Äôs Libra!  Libra, you may recall, was the first iteration of a Facebook-backed crypto project that wanted to ‚Äúbank the unbanked.‚Äù It would have been a digital coin backed by a basket of fiat currencies, Treasurys and other financial instruments. (Mysten was founded by former Meta Platforms. ‚Äì formerly Facebook ‚Äì engineers.) Roubini‚Äôs project is similarly ambitious ‚Äì creating an alternative safe haven asset to U.S. Treasurys that also has ‚Äúpayment features.‚Äù It might also offer yield, making it more attractive to hold, although in a blog post, Roubini notes that USG‚Äôs fluctuating value may limit its use as a form of payment. Still, USG wouldn‚Äôt exactly compete with the dollar and could complement a central bank digital currency, Roubini suggested.  Indeed, the world is changing and the economy is getting ‚Ä¶ weirder. And a lot of potential solutions.  The beauty of the industry isn‚Äôt that it pretends to have the answers, but that it is willing to experiment. Î≥∏Î¨∏: TerraUSD (UST) has lost its dollar peg for the second time in three days, falling to as low as $0.65 on Monday, according to the most recent price estimates from CoinMarketCap.  As UST has "depegged," the price of LUNA, its sister token, has dropped over 44% to $35 in the past 24 hours according to CoinMarketCap.  UST, a so-called algorithmic stablecoin, works with LUNA to maintain a price of $1 using a set of on-chain mint and burn mechanics. In theory, these mechanics work to ensure traders can always swap $1 worth of UST for $1 worth of Luna, which has a floating price and is meant to serve as a kind of shock absorber for UST's price.  Luna's price decline puts its market cap below that of UST's. That potentially throws the foundation of UST's entire stabilizing mechanism into jeopardy, because it means a Terra bank run could lead to some users no longer being able to redeem their $1 of UST for $1 of LUNA.  Read More: What is LUNA and UST? A Guide to the Terra Ecosystem  UST‚Äôs earlier loss of its $1 peg this weekend, which saw the token dip to $0.985 on Saturday before recovering to the $1 mark on Sunday, wasn't the first or the largest ‚Äúdepeg‚Äù event in Terra‚Äôs history, but it marked the first time the algorithmic stablecoin slipped below $1 since it embarked on a much-publicized bid to build out bitcoin and avalanche reserves.  Major stress  Today‚Äôs depeg comes after the Luna Foundation Guard (LFG) announced Sunday night that $1.5 billion of its massive bitcoin reserves would be ‚Äúloaned‚Äù out to professional market makers to proactively defend UST‚Äôs dollar peg.  Monday's events were "the biggest stress test the system has ever faced," Jos√© Maria Macedo ‚Äì a partner at Delphi Digital and an LFG council member who helps manage the group's reserves ‚Äì told CoinDesk. But he added that the UST-LUNA market cap flip is not a cause for concern because of LFG's reserves.  Shortly after Macedo's call with CoinDesk, Terra appeared to empty out all of the funds (around $1.3 billion) from its confirmed bitcoin address. Professional market makers are apparently using the BTC reserves to defend UST's dollar peg on protocols like Curve, which allows people to swap between UST and other currencies like the dollar-backed USDC and Tether stablecoins.  Currently, there is no concrete link between the LFG reserves and Terra's on-chain mint and burn mechanism. There are proposals to bake Terra's bitcoin reserves into its underlying smart contracts, but there's currently no way for users to directly redeem UST or LUNA for bitcoin.  Whether this will ever be possible has become even more unclear now that the reserves look to have been drained almost entirely.  On CoinDesk TV on Monday morning, Swan Bitcoin CEO Cory Klippsten called Terra a ‚Äúconfidence game‚Äù in response to the outsized influence of Terra‚Äôs founders and big-money backers in actively working to help the currency maintain its peg. In a different section of the Hacker House, past empanada-hawking food trucks and among other ‚ÄúNFT Metaverse‚Äù exhibitors, the gaming company has a booth with several screens showing Star Atlas' high-quality animation ‚Äì most of what the company has to publicly show for its work so far.  The ships look like vehicles out of ‚ÄúStar Wars,‚Äù or perhaps the video game Star Citizen, which inspired Daniel Floyd‚Äôs vision for the game. Quiroga is hanging by the screens, and he describes first meeting Wagner back in Nevada. While standing behind him on line in a coffee shop, Quiroga commented on his cycling keychain ‚Äì they‚Äôre both cyclists and started riding together, and during one of those earlier rides, Wagner introduced Quiroga to blockchain. That‚Äôs key, because Wagner said he believes ‚Äúgaming will bring the next billion users into crypto.‚Äù  He also brings up the ability to create more complex systems in Solana, which offers low transaction costs along with limited lag time during gaming scenarios. ‚ÄúIf you're running around and you shoot a bullet and it doesn't shoot and then you die, you're mad,‚Äù he says.  The game has to run smoothly ‚Äì the point, after all, is to create a Triple-A game on a blockchain that will appeal to current gamers, crypto natives and play-to-earners in developing countries.  Plus, Wagner and his team want the game to be as immersive as possible ‚Äì both a fun escape for players, but also truly another world they can live in, a place to buy cannabis and govern their communities and have a virtual job where they can make real money.  ‚ÄúAll activities that are taking place online right now, they're going to be reproduced in some way in these immersive, three-dimensional digital worlds,‚Äù Wagner says. While Wagner admits none of this can solve social stratification, the game can ‚Äúenable people to collaborate more freely.‚Äù  This is all a lot to digest ‚Äì a metaverse that‚Äôs a totally fictional sci-fi game where people can get real jobs and, yes, even hire Web 3-inclined musicians to host real (but digital) concerts that people/avatars can attend if they hold the right digital tokens that they paid for with IRL fiat currency. They can form DAOs to buy ships or make political decisions within this fake reality that can potentially make or break their real-life fortunes. It all makes you think ‚Äì is it a problem if people become too far removed from their physical environments, too immersed in a false reality to the point where the line between what‚Äôs real and what‚Äôs fabricated blurs beyond recognition? Îâ¥Ïä§Ï†úÎ™©: How Big Is Crypto Crime, Really?
Î≥∏Î¨∏: The European Union is in late-stage talks over how to implement new rules intended to curb dodgy behavior that uses virtual assets ‚Äì but estimates of the share of crypto payments linked to financial crime vary wildly from 0.15% to a whopping 46% of transaction volumes.  There‚Äôs clearly a lot of illicit activity in the crypto world ‚Äì of which some, like scams or hacks, are harmful to honest crypto users, while others might seem like a way of circumventing rules that were unfair in the first place, like government-imposed capital controls.  People in the crypto industry like to quote the figures on the lower end of the range, and on Friday, Binance‚Äôs CEO Changpeng ‚ÄúCZ‚Äù Zhao tweeted statistics to argue that crypto is safer than fiat.  But attempting to get a handle on the exact scale of unlawful virtual asset activity isn‚Äôt easy. It usually relies on identifying crypto addresses that appear suspect and totting up their trade volume ‚Äì but illicit users generally prefer to hide in the shadows.  The result you get depends on how much certainty you want to have about who the illicit actors are online. When branding a wallet address as suspect, you might want to have a smoking gun that constitutes absolute proof, or be happy to accept something more probabilistic and speculative.  For regulators, judges and law enforcement, understanding the problem could prove crucial to determining whether new laws to force crypto users to identify themselves are needed or even lawful.  Yet there‚Äôs surprisingly little consensus on how big crypto crime is. Almost certainly, in dollar terms, it‚Äôs dwarfed by the real-life version. According to the U.N. Office on Drugs and Crime, money laundering through conventional finance is worth as much as $2 trillion, comparable to the total value of all the world‚Äôs crypto markets combined.  But regulators are worried not just about the overall volumes, but what they represent as a share of the crypto sector. They‚Äôve noted how fast virtual assets are gaining popularity, and are thinking about what the scale of the problem might be in future, not just today.  In a recent speech that criticized the industry as akin to a lawless Wild West, the European Central Bank‚Äôs Fabio Panetta cited a wide range of figures for illicit crypto activity, ranging from under 1% to as much as half of all virtual transactions.  Read more: ECB's Panetta Blasts Crypto as 'Ponzi Scheme' Fueled by Greed  One reason for variation in figures is whether you look at, say, drug purchases as a share of crypto payments or compared to the overall market. People who acquire bitcoin (BTC) just to "HODL" aren‚Äôt doing anything wrong ‚Äì but that means a greater proportion of those using it to buy something are likely to be engaging in illicit activity.  Which wallet?  But beyond the question of exactly what you‚Äôre counting, there‚Äôs also a question of how you‚Äôre counting these transactions ‚Äì and that all depends on how you determine who the bad actors are.  Industry figures and academics such as CZ, or Georgetown Law‚Äôs Chris Brummer, often quote figures from blockchain specialists Chainalysis ‚Äì which said in January that transactions involving illicit addresses represented just 0.15% of cryptocurrency transaction volumes last year.  But that approach leaves plenty of crimes unaccounted for, CoinDesk was told by Sean Foley, an associate professor of applied finance at Macquarie University in Australia.  Foley‚Äôs own paper, evocatively titled ‚ÄúSex, Drugs, and Bitcoin,‚Äù was peer-reviewed and published in the Review of Financial Studies in 2019. It concluded that one-quarter of bitcoin users are involved in illegal activity, and that the $76 billion in illicit payments involving bitcoin represented 46% of the currency‚Äôs total transactions.  That‚Äôs a much higher estimate than others on the market ‚Äì but Foley defended his methods in an interview with CoinDesk.  Chainalysis ‚Äúare not necessarily very transparent in their approach,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey don't really accurately document how they arrive at their numbers.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIf Chainalysis only looked at Ross Ulbricht‚Äôs wallet that was seized by the FBI, but I look at all of his conduct through time. ... I'm going to find a lot more,‚Äù he said, referring to the founder of the Silk Road marketplace who was sentenced to jail in 2015.  Rather than just looking at addresses known to be suspect, Foley looked at each users‚Äô networks and behaviors, using statistical techniques that are also deployed in fields like medicine and nuclear safety.  While, say, using a mixer to stay anonymous isn‚Äôt a smoking gun proving bad behavior, he says that taken together, different indicators can give you a good view about whether someone is up to no good.  ‚ÄúIf you look dodgy because you were predominantly interacting with dodgy people, and you look dodgy because you were using a lot of tumbling services, and there was a lot of activity when darknet marketplaces got seized ‚Ä¶ this gives us the ability to say with a much higher degree of confidence that these are likely illicit actors,‚Äù he said.  Too far?  Others warn Foley might have gone too far, unfairly tainting innocent crypto users by association.  ‚ÄúYou have to be really careful with crime data and the associations that you make between wallets,‚Äù Kim Grauer, Chainalysis‚Äô head of research, told CoinDesk. Chainalysis says that illicit wallets received $14 billion in 2021, a figure much lower than Foley‚Äôs.  ‚ÄúA lot of times people will just see money transacting between a crime wallet and another wallet and they'll say, ‚Äòhey, those must be connected,‚Äô‚Äù she said ‚Äì citing examples such as when a single service managed millions of different addresses.  The ‚Äúquirky‚Äù nature of blockchain means that ‚Äúif you are not a crime investigator with blockchain experience, I would be a little bit skeptical of some of the definitive associations,‚Äù she said.  Chainalysis‚Äô own data, in contrast to Foley‚Äôs, ‚Äúis not extrapolated, it's not statistically determined,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is the real amount of transactions that are identified as illicit from a data set that's the most powerful data set on cryptocurrency in the world.‚Äù  The Chainalysis figure still isn‚Äôt all encompassing, she acknowledged. It doesn‚Äôt include real-life crimes like street drug deals that then get laundered via bitcoin, nor gray areas like wash trading ‚Äì the fake sales intended to push up market prices that appear to be becoming more common in the market for non-fungible tokens.  Scams can often only be identified after the rug is pulled, meaning the data for a given year can lag behind and needs to be updated. But, she said that an approach based on ‚Äúhundreds of hundreds‚Äù of investigators sleuthing darknet forums looking for crime is ‚Äúdefinitely, definitely fair.‚Äù  Read more: Europe's Lawmakers Set to Advance Discussion of Controversial Crypto AML Rules  Too old?  A further wrinkle is how rapidly data ages in such a fast moving market. The data Foley used dates back to 2017 ‚Äì a lifetime ago, in the crypto world ‚Äì but, if anything, he thinks the problem has only increased since then.  He acknowledges illicit bitcoin volumes have probably fallen over time ‚Äì but only because wrongdoers turned to less ostentatious alternatives, such as ZCash, Monero and Dash.  ‚ÄúThere's a lot of privacy technology that has been developed since the publication of our paper,‚Äù he said, and he believes that overall the criminal use of crypto ‚Äúis not going down.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThere's still a ton of online marketplaces for darknet products, so I don't think that's gone away,‚Äù he said ‚Äì and also cited the rise in industrial-scale ransomware like the $5 million 2021 hack of Colonial Pipeline.  Regulators unconvinced  The people who really need to be convinced are, of course, the Financial Action Task Force, the international body responsible for developing money laundering norms for conventional finance and the crypto sector ‚Äì including the controversial travel rule that the EU is now trying to implement.  In a report published in July 2021, FATF noticed significant variations in estimates of illicit crypto trades both over time and among different analysts, such as Chainalysis, Elliptic and Merkle Science ‚Äì which could be, Grauer said, because they look at a different universe of transactions or currencies.  Whatever the reason, FATF believes that the analysts‚Äô estimates of the percentage of transactions that are unlawful, which range from 0.1% to 15.4%, are all too low.  ‚ÄúThe data provided only relates to identified illicit transactions which the companies are able to identify, based on lists of known or suspected illicit addresses,‚Äù the FATF report said. Figures from the likes of Chainalysis should be ‚Äútreated as the likely minimum,‚Äù it concluded.  Grauer also seems to concede that point ‚Äì saying that her favored figure ‚Äúis a floor for the amount of illicit activity.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWe wouldn't know how many [illicit actors] were missing,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou don't know what you don't know ‚Ä¶ if we knew about it, we would put it in our system.‚Äù  In the end, Foley and Grauer may have come up with different results because they have different aims. In the former case, it‚Äôs seeking to estimate the overall volumes linked to crime, and in the latter, identifying individual users who might be worth pursuing ‚Äì something that requires a much higher burden of proof.  Methods like Foley‚Äôs are ‚Äúcertainly extremely useful,‚Äù Grauer said, but she warned that ‚Äúresults should not be relied on when it comes to identifying illicit wallets.‚Äù  ‚ÄúPeople use our data set to run full investigations, including putting people in jail,‚Äù she said ‚Äì so she won‚Äôt blacklist someone lightly.  This matters for live policy. In March, the European Parliament voted to introduce new checks on the identities of those making even the smallest crypto payments ‚Äì including, most controversially, when transactions are made with unhosted wallets that aren‚Äôt managed by a regulated exchange.  The idea ‚Äì whose details still need to be finalized with national governments ‚Äì is that law enforcement would then be able to more easily track crypto transactions that could be used to fund serious crimes, such as terrorism or child pornography. But the move met with a slew of opposition from industry players such as Coinbase (COIN), who said the bill could stifle innovation and harm privacy.  Laws that invade privacy more than they need to could get struck down, legal experts, such as Amsterdam University‚Äôs Thibaut Schrepel, told CoinDesk. That message seems to have gotten through to officials, such as the European Commission‚Äôs Gabriel Hugonnot, who has warned lawmakers that they would need to justify attempts to treat crypto differently from other kinds of financial transfers.  In considering whether the law is really needed, policymakers ‚Äì and, eventually, judges ‚Äì could be swayed by figures on the overall scale of the crypto crime problem, and by other features of crypto tech like the transparency of the network.  However imprecise the figures are, the kind of analysis possible on the blockchain is still much better than offline financial-crime stats, Grauer reckons.  ‚ÄúThere is no equivalent number in the fiat world, because doing this type of research is just not possible,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúUsing U.S. dollars, how many drug dealers are there in the world? There's never a number you're going to get.‚Äù  But, ultimately, good policies come from good data ‚Äì and it may be in short supply.
